text: today on the caucus Jackie comms on a
perilous moment for House Speaker John
Boehner before Republican colleagues
this morning he reportedly used very
blunt language to try and get wavering
members on board also today john harwood
reports from inside mitt romney's
campaign headquarters in New Hampshire
we've gotten off to a good start without
a lot of work to do yet whether we get
it tonight tomorrow or the next day the
Boehner plan is not going to pass why
because it is not a solution so here we
are just days short of a week before the
deadline for raising the debt limit and
we sort of seems like we're farther away
from a resolve than we were say a week
ago the Boehner plan was already in a
bit of trouble with House Republicans
you know a lot of them simply don't want
to raise the debt limit at all but it
the real killer for it came late on
Monday when the Congressional Budget
Office scored it as we say and found
that it would cut spending over the next
decade just eight hundred and fifty
billion instead of the more than a
trillion that Speaker Boehner had said
meanwhile harry reid senate majority
leader has gotten a CBO score for his
bill that shows over 2 trillion in
savings over 10 years this is an
extremely important test of Speaker
Boehner speakership in his leadership if
you can't lead your own party conference
how much of a leader are you a lot of
his members you're not back and what he
is proposed or what just about anybody's
proposed they want much more than there
ever going to be able to get and not
just from the Senate Democrats but also
from Republicans in the Senate many of
whom would not vote for something as
far-reaching as the House Republicans
would want in terms of deep spending
cuts and remaking programs like Medicare
I mean his speakership could really be
in danger here ultimately so the house
is put off its vote until Thursday and
if the House bill were the House
Republicans bill were to go down it
clearly leaves the ball in the court of
the Senate Harry Reid the Democrat and
Mitch McConnell the Republican leader
have been working together off and on on
something anyway if the Senate moves as
many people think will happen and passes
something and send it to the house it
will really be take it or leave it the
question is whether Speaker Boehner
would bring that kind of compromise
whatever it is to a vote on the House
floor because he's very likely to lose a
majority of his own party he'll need
Democratic votes and so it'll be a big
test for him as to whether he's willing
to bring legislation to the floor that
only can pass perhaps with a majority of
Democrats votes
even at a time of all this intense in
fighting over the debt limit in
Washington it's a relatively quiet
moment on the Republican presidential
campaign trail especially here in New
Hampshire and that's probably a good
thing for Mitt Romney the front-runner
here he's running as somebody who can
fix the economy he doesn't want to get
his fingerprints too deeply onto the
dead fight in Washington which isn't
making anybody look good so you've got a
relatively low-key effort here I had say
to use the word frontrunner I think this
is really a wide open process you do
need to win New Hampshire don't you well
I think when you do too well in New
Hampshire Mitt Romney's in a position
with a 20-point lead in New Hampshire
much larger than his national lead over
the field of trying to hold on to that
as the pace of the campaign and the
competition intensifies the one thing
that we know is that the field may not
be set Rick Perry the governor of Texas
may get in he could pose some intense
competition from the right you've also
got Jon Huntsman the former governor of
Utah who has announced plans to ramp up
his staff in the state it really hasn't
started in terms of voter engagement
when we start seeing television
advertisements in the fall we'll see
whether or not Mitt Romney can sustain
or withstand the attacks over the issue
of flip-flopping that's something he
faced in 2008 and in particular in the
era of the Tea Party whether he can take
the attacks over having supported a
health care plan in the state of
Massachusetts that many people think
resembles President Obama's health care
plan in Washington
